ces ]=20



History [ [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=3DWorld_Wide_Web&act=
ion=3Dedit&section=3D1 | edit ] ]=20
Main article: [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_World_Wide_Web=
 | History of the World Wide Web ]=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:NeXTcube_first_webserver.JPG ]=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:NeXTcube_first_webserver.JPG ]=20
The NeXT Computer used by [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee |=
 Tim Berners-Lee ] at [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CERN | CERN ] .=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:CERN_web_corridor.jpg ]=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:CERN_web_corridor.jpg ]=20
The corridor where WWW was born. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CERN | CER=
N ] , ground floor of building No.1=20


Berners-Lee's vision of a global hyperlinked information system became a po=
ssibility by the second half of the 1980s. By 1985 the global Internet bega=
n to proliferate in Europe and in the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domai=
n_Name_System | Domain Name System ] (which the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/=
wiki/Uniform_Resource_Locator | Uniform Resource Locator ] is built upon) c=
ame into being. In 1988 the first direct IP connection between Europe and N=
orth America was made and Berners-Lee began to openly discuss the possibili=
ty of a web-like system at CERN. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide=
_Web#cite_note-7 | [7] ]=20


In March 1989 Tim Berners-Lee issued a proposal to the management at CERN f=
or a system called "Mesh" that referenced [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E=
NQUIRE | ENQUIRE ] , a database and software project he had built in 1980, =
which used the term "web" and described a more elaborate information manage=
ment system based on links embedded in readable text: "Imagine, then, the r=
eferences in this document all being associated with the network address of=
 the thing to which they referred, so that while reading this document you =
could skip to them with a click of the mouse." Such a system, he explained,=
 could be referred to using one of the existing meanings of the word [ http=
s://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypertext | hypertext ] , a term that he says was=
 coined in the 1950s. There is no reason, the proposal continues, why such =
hypertext links could not encompass multimedia documents including graphics=
, speech and video, so that Berners-Lee goes on to use the term [ https://e=
n.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypermedia | hypermedia ] . [ https://en.wikipedia.org=
/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-8 | [8] ]=20


With help from his colleague and fellow hypertext enthusiast [ https://en.w=
ikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Cailliau | Robert Cailliau ] he published a more f=
ormal proposal on 12 November 1990 to build a "Hypertext project" called "W=
orldWideWeb" (one word) as a "web" of "hypertext documents" to be viewed by=
 " [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_browser | browsers ] " using a [ htt=
ps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Client%E2%80%93server_architecture | client=E2=
=80=93server architecture ] . [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_We=
b#cite_note-W90-9 | [9] ] At this point HTML and HTTP had already been in d=
evelopment for about two months and the first Web server was about a month =
from completing its first successful test.=20

This proposal estimated that a read-only web would be developed within thre=
e months and that it would take six months to achieve "the creation of new =
links and new material by readers, [so that] authorship becomes universal" =
as well as "the automatic notification of a reader when new material of int=
erest to him/her has become available." While the read-only goal was met, a=
ccessible authorship of web content took longer to mature, with the [ https=
://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wiki | wiki ] concept, [ https://en.wikipedia.org/=
wiki/WebDAV | WebDAV ] , [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blog | blogs ] , [=
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_2.0 | Web 2.0 ] and [ https://en.wikiped=
ia.org/wiki/RSS | RSS ] / [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atom_(standard) |=
 Atom ] . [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-10 | [10=
] ]=20


The proposal was modeled after the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SGML | S=
GML ] reader [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynatext | Dynatext ] by Elect=
ronic Book Technology, a spin-off from the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/=
Institute_for_Research_in_Information_and_Scholarship | Institute for Resea=
rch in Information and Scholarship ] at [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bro=
wn_University | Brown University ] . The Dynatext system, licensed by CERN,=
 was a key player in the extension of SGML ISO 8879:1986 to Hypermedia with=
in [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HyTime | HyTime ] , but it was considere=
d too expensive and had an inappropriate licensing policy for use in the ge=
neral high energy physics community, namely a fee for each document and eac=
h document alteration.=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cern_datacenter.jpg ]=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cern_datacenter.jpg ]=20
The CERN [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_center | data center ] in 201=
0 housing some WWW servers=20


A [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NeXT_Computer | NeXT Computer ] was used =
by Berners-Lee as the world's first [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_ser=
ver | web server ] and also to write the first [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w=
iki/Web_browser | web browser ] , [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WorldWide=
Web | WorldWideWeb ] , in 1990. By Christmas 1990, Berners-Lee had built al=
l the tools necessary for a working Web: [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wo=
rld_Wide_Web#cite_note-11 | [11] ] the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worl=
dWideWeb | first web browser ] (which was a web editor as well) and the fir=
st web server. The first web site, [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wi=
de_Web#cite_note-12 | [12] ] which described the project itself, was publis=
hed on 20 December 1990. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cit=
e_note-13 | [13] ]=20


The first web page may be lost, but [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Jo=
nes_(computer_technologist) | Paul Jones ] of [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wi=
ki/UNC-Chapel_Hill | UNC-Chapel Hill ] in North Carolina announced in May 2=
013 that Berners-Lee gave him what he says is the oldest known web page dur=
ing a 1991 visit to UNC. Jones stored it on a [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wi=
ki/Magneto-optical_drive | magneto-optical drive ] and on his NeXT computer=
. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-14 | [14] ]=20


On 6 August 1991, Berners-Lee published a short summary of the World Wide W=
eb project on the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newsgroup | newsgroup ] a=
lt.hypertext . [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-15 =
| [15] ] This date also marked the debut of the Web as a publicly available=
 service on the Internet, although new users only accessed it after 23 Augu=
st. For this reason this is considered the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/=
Internaut | internaut ] 's day. Several newsmedia have reported that the fi=
rst photo on the Web was published by Berners-Lee in 1992, an image of the =
CERN house band [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Les_Horribles_Cernettes | L=
es Horribles Cernettes ] taken by Silvano de Gennaro; Gennaro has disclaime=
d this story, writing that media were "totally distorting our words for the=
 sake of cheap sensationalism." [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_=
Web#cite_note-16 | [16] ]=20


The first server outside Europe was installed at the [ https://en.wikipedia=
.org/wiki/SLAC_National_Accelerator_Laboratory | Stanford Linear Accelerato=
r Center ] (SLAC) in Palo Alto, California, to host the [ https://en.wikipe=
dia.org/wiki/SPIRES | SPIRES-HEP ] database. Accounts differ substantially =
as to the date of this event. The World Wide Web Consortium's timeline says=
 December 1992, [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-17=
 | [17] ] whereas SLAC itself claims December 1991, [ https://en.wikipedia.=
org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-18 | [18] ] [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wi=
ki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-19 | [19] ] as does a W3C document titled A Lit=
tle History of the World Wide Web . [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_W=
ide_Web#cite_note-20 | [20] ]=20


The underlying concept of hypertext originated in previous projects from th=
e 1960s, such as the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypertext_Editing_Syst=
em | Hypertext Editing System ] (HES) at Brown University, [ https://en.wik=
ipedia.org/wiki/Ted_Nelson | Ted Nelson ] 's [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wik=
i/Project_Xanadu | Project Xanadu ] , and [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D=
ouglas_Engelbart | Douglas Engelbart ] 's [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N=
LS_(computer_system) | oN-Line System ] (NLS). Both Nelson and Engelbart we=
re in turn inspired by [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vannevar_Bush | Vann=
evar Bush ] 's [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microfilm | microfilm ] -bas=
ed [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memex | memex ] , which was described in=
 the 1945 essay " [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/As_We_May_Think | As We M=
ay Think ] ". [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-Conk=
ling-21 | [21] ]=20


Berners-Lee's breakthrough was to marry hypertext to the Internet. In his b=
ook [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weaving_the_Web:_The_Original_Design_an=
d_Ultimate_Destiny_of_the_World_Wide_Web_by_its_inventor | Weaving The Web =
] , he explains that he had repeatedly suggested that a marriage between th=
e two technologies was possible to members of both technical communities, b=
ut when no one took up his invitation, he finally assumed the project himse=
lf. In the process, he developed three essential technologies:=20

    * a system of globally unique identifiers for resources on the Web and =
elsewhere, the universal document identifier (UDI), later known as [ https:=
//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_resource_locator | uniform resource locator=
 ] (URL) and [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_resource_identifier | =
uniform resource identifier ] (URI);=20
    * the publishing language [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypertext_Mar=
kup_Language | HyperText Markup Language ] (HTML);=20
    * the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypertext_Transfer_Protocol | Hyp=
ertext Transfer Protocol ] (HTTP). [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wi=
de_Web#cite_note-22 | [22] ]=20



The World Wide Web had a number of differences from other hypertext systems=
 available at the time. The Web required only unidirectional links rather t=
han bidirectional ones, making it possible for someone to link to another r=
esource without action by the owner of that resource. It also significantly=
 reduced the difficulty of implementing web servers and browsers (in compar=
ison to earlier systems), but in turn presented the chronic problem of [ ht=
tps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Link_rot | link rot ] .=20

Unlike predecessors such as [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HyperCard | Hyp=
erCard ] , the World Wide Web was non-proprietary, making it possible to de=
velop servers and clients independently and to add extensions without licen=
sing restrictions. On 30 April 1993, CERN announced that the World Wide Web=
 would be free to anyone, with no fees due. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki=
/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-23 | [23] ] Coming two months after the announcem=
ent that the server implementation of the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G=
opher_(protocol) | Gopher ] protocol was no longer free to use, this produc=
ed a rapid shift away from Gopher and towards the Web. An early popular web=
 browser was [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ViolaWWW | ViolaWWW ] for [ ht=
tps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix | Unix ] and the [ https://en.wikipedia.or=
g/wiki/X_Windowing_System | X Windowing System ] .=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cailliau_Abramatic_Berners-Lee_10_year=
s_WWW_consortium.png ]=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cailliau_Abramatic_Berners-Lee_10_year=
s_WWW_consortium.png ]=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Cailliau | Robert Cailliau ] , Jean-=
Fran=C3=A7ois Abramatic formerly of [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_=
Institute_for_Research_in_Computer_Science_and_Automation | INRIA ] , and [=
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee | Tim Berners-Lee ] at the 1=
0th anniversary of the World Wide Web Consortium.=20


Scholars generally agree that a turning point for the World Wide Web began =
with the introduction [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_n=
ote-24 | [24] ] of the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosaic_(web_browser)=
 | Mosaic ] web browser [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite=
_note-25 | [25] ] in 1993, a graphical browser developed by a team at the [=
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Center_for_Supercomputing_Applicati=
ons | National Center for Supercomputing Applications ] at the [ https://en=
.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Illinois_at_Urbana-Champaign | University=
 of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign ] (NCSA-UIUC), led by [ https://en.wikiped=
ia.org/wiki/Marc_Andreessen | Marc Andreessen ] . Funding for Mosaic came f=
rom the U.S. High-Performance Computing and Communications Initiative and t=
he [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_Performance_Computing_and_Communica=
tion_Act_of_1991 | High Performance Computing and Communication Act of 1991=
 ] , one of [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al_Gore_and_information_technol=
ogy | several computing developments initiated by U.S. Senator Al Gore ] . =
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-26 | [26] ] Prior =
to the release of Mosaic, graphics were not commonly mixed with text in web=
 pages and the web's popularity was less than older protocols in use over t=
he Internet, such as [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gopher_(protocol) | Go=
pher ] and [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wide_Area_Information_Servers | =
Wide Area Information Servers ] (WAIS). Mosaic's graphical user interface a=
llowed the Web to become, by far, the most popular Internet protocol.=20

The [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web_Consortium | World Wide =
Web Consortium ] (W3C) was founded by Tim Berners-Lee after he left the Eur=
opean Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) in October 1994. It was foun=
ded at the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Techn=
ology | Massachusetts Institute of Technology ] Laboratory for Computer Sci=
ence (MIT/LCS) with support from the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defens=
e_Advanced_Research_Projects_Agency | Defense Advanced Research Projects Ag=
ency ] (DARPA), which had pioneered the Internet; a year later, a second si=
te was founded at [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/INRIA | INRIA ] (a French=
 national computer research lab) with support from the [ https://en.wikiped=
ia.org/wiki/European_Commission | European Commission ] DG InfSo; and in 19=
96, a third continental site was created in Japan at [ https://en.wikipedia=
.org/wiki/Keio_University | Keio University ] . By the end of 1994, the tot=
al number of websites was still relatively small, but many [ https://en.wik=
ipedia.org/wiki/List_of_websites_founded_before_1995 | notable websites ] w=
ere already active that foreshadowed or inspired today's most popular servi=
ces.=20

Connected by the existing Internet, other websites were created around the =
world, adding international standards for [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D=
omain_name | domain names ] and [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML | HTML=
 ] . Since then, Berners-Lee has played an active role in guiding the devel=
opment of web standards (such as the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markup=
_language | markup languages ] to compose web pages in), and has advocated =
his vision of a [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Web | Semantic Web=
 ] . The World Wide Web enabled the spread of information over the Internet=
 through an easy-to-use and flexible format. It thus played an important ro=
le in popularizing use of the Internet. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wor=
ld_Wide_Web#cite_note-27 | [27] ] Although the two terms are sometimes [ ht=
tps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conflation | conflated ] in popular use, World =
Wide Web is not [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synonym | synonymous ] with=
 Internet . [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-28 | [=
28] ] The Web is an [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_space | inf=
ormation space ] containing hyperlinked documents and other [ https://en.wi=
kipedia.org/wiki/Web_resource | resources ] , identified by their URIs. [ h=
ttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-29 | [29] ] It is imp=
lemented as both client and server software using Internet protocols such a=
s [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TCP/IP | TCP/IP ] and [ https://en.wikipe=
dia.org/wiki/HTTP | HTTP ] .=20

Tim Berners-Lee was [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of_the_British_Em=
pire | knighted ] in 2004 by Queen [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elizabet=
h_II | Elizabeth II ] for "services to the global development of the Intern=
et". [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-gaz-30 | [30]=
 ] [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-31 | [31] ]=20
Function [ [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=3DWorld_Wide_Web&ac=
tion=3Dedit&section=3D2 | edit ] ]=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Internet_Key_Layers.png ]=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Internet_Key_Layers.png ]=20
The World Wide Web functions as a layer on top of the Internet, helping to =
make it more functional. The advent of the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/=
Mosaic_(web_browser) | Mosaic ] web browser helped to make the web much mor=
e usable.=20


The terms Internet and World Wide Web are often used without much distincti=
on. However, the two are not the same. The Internet is a global system of i=
nterconnected [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_networks | computer =
networks ] . In contrast, the World Wide Web is one of the services transfe=
rred over these networks. It is a collection of text documents and other re=
sources, linked by hyperlinks and URLs, usually accessed by [ https://en.wi=
kipedia.org/wiki/Web_browser | web browsers ] , from web servers. [ https:/=
/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-32 | [32] ]=20


Viewing a [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_page | web page ] on the Worl=
d Wide Web normally begins either by typing the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/=
wiki/Uniform_resource_locator | URL ] of the page into a web browser, or by=
 following a hyperlink to that page or resource. The web browser then initi=
ates a series of background communication messages to fetch and display the=
 requested page. In the 1990s, using a browser to view web pages=E2=80=94an=
d to move from one web page to another through hyperlinks=E2=80=94came to b=
e known as 'browsing,' 'web surfing' (after [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki=
/Channel_surfing | channel surfing ] ), or 'navigating the Web'. Early stud=
ies of this new behavior investigated user patterns in using web browsers. =
One study, for example, found five user patterns: exploratory surfing, wind=
ow surfing, evolved surfing, bounded navigation and targeted navigation. [ =
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-33 | [33] ]=20


The following example demonstrates the functioning of a web browser when ac=
cessing a page at the URL http://www.example.org/home.html . The browser re=
solves the server name of the URL ( www.example.org ) into an [ https://en.=
wikipedia.org/wiki/IP_address | Internet Protocol address ] using the globa=
lly distributed [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_Name_System | Domain=
 Name System ] (DNS). This lookup returns an IP address such as 203.0.113.4=
 . The browser then requests the resource by sending an [ https://en.wikipe=
dia.org/wiki/Hypertext_Transfer_Protocol | HTTP ] request across the Intern=
et to the computer at that address. It requests service from a specific TCP=
 port number that is well known for the HTTP service, so that the receiving=
 host can distinguish an HTTP request from other network protocols it may b=
e servicing. The HTTP protocol normally uses [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wik=
i/List_of_TCP_and_UDP_port_numbers | port number 80 ] . The content of the =
HTTP request can be as simple as two lines of text:=20
GET /home.html HTTP / 1.1 Host : www.example.org=20


The computer receiving the HTTP request delivers it to web server software =
listening for requests on port 80. If the web server can fulfill the reques=
t it sends an HTTP response back to the browser indicating success:=20
HTTP / 1.0 200 OK Content-Type : text/html; charset=3DUTF-8=20


followed by the content of the requested page. HyperText Markup Language ( =
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML | HTML ] ) for a basic web page might =
look like this:=20
<html> <head> <title> Example.org =E2=80=93 The World Wide Web </title> </h=
ead> <body> <p> The World Wide Web, abbreviated as WWW and commonly known .=
.. </p> </body> </html>=20


The web browser [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsing | parses ] the HTML=
 and interprets the markup ( <title> , <p> for paragraph, and such) that su=
rrounds the words to format the text on the screen. Many web pages use HTML=
 to reference the URLs of other resources such as images, other embedded me=
dia, [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Client-side_scripting | scripts ] that=
 affect page behavior, and [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascading_Style_=
Sheets | Cascading Style Sheets ] that affect page layout. The browser make=
s additional HTTP requests to the web server for these other [ https://en.w=
ikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_media_type | Internet media types ] . As it rece=
ives their content from the web server, the browser progressively [ https:/=
/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Layout_engine | renders ] the page onto the screen a=
s specified by its HTML and these additional resources. Linking [ [ https:/=
/en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=3DWorld_Wide_Web&action=3Dedit&section=
=3D3 | edit ] ]=20


Most web pages contain hyperlinks to other related pages and perhaps to dow=
nloadable files, source documents, definitions and other web resources. In =
the underlying HTML, a hyperlink looks like this: < a href =3D "http://www.=
example.org/home.html" > Example.org Homepage </ a >=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:WorldWideWebAroundWikipedia.png ]=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:WorldWideWebAroundWikipedia.png ]=20
Graphic representation of a minute fraction of the WWW, demonstrating [ htt=
ps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperlink | hyperlinks ]=20


Such a collection of useful, related resources, interconnected via hypertex=
t links is dubbed a web of information. Publication on the Internet created=
 what Tim Berners-Lee first called the WorldWideWeb (in its original [ http=
s://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CamelCase | CamelCase ] , which was subsequently =
discarded) in November 1990. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web=
#cite_note-W90-9 | [9] ]=20


The hyperlink structure of the WWW is described by the [ https://en.wikiped=
ia.org/wiki/Webgraph | webgraph ] : the nodes of the webgraph correspond to=
 the web pages (or URLs) the directed edges between them to the hyperlinks.=
=20

Over time, many web resources pointed to by hyperlinks disappear, relocate,=
 or are replaced with different content. This makes hyperlinks obsolete, a =
phenomenon referred to in some circles as link rot, and the hyperlinks affe=
cted by it are often called [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dead_link | dea=
d links ] . The ephemeral nature of the Web has prompted many efforts to ar=
chive web sites. The [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Archive | Int=
ernet Archive ] , active since 1996, is the best known of such efforts. Dyn=
amic updates of web pages [ [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=3D=
World_Wide_Web&action=3Dedit&section=3D4 | edit ] ]=20
Main article: [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajax_(programming) | Ajax (pr=
ogramming) ]=20


[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JavaScript | JavaScript ] is a [ https://en=
.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scripting_programming_language | scripting language ] t=
hat was initially developed in 1995 by [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bren=
dan_Eich | Brendan Eich ] , then of [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netscap=
e | Netscape ] , for use within web pages. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/=
World_Wide_Web#cite_note-Hamilton-34 | [34] ] The standardised version is [=
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECMAScript | ECMAScript ] . [ https://en.wik=
ipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-Hamilton-34 | [34] ] To make web p=
ages more interactive, some web applications also use JavaScript techniques=
 such as [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajax_(programming) | Ajax ] ( [ ht=
tps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchronous_I/O | asynchronous ] JavaScript an=
d [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XML | XML ] ). [ https://en.wikipedia.org=
/wiki/Client-side_scripting | Client-side script ] is delivered with the pa=
ge that can make additional HTTP requests to the server, either in response=
 to user actions such as mouse movements or clicks, or based on elapsed tim=
e. The server's responses are used to modify the current page rather than c=
reating a new page with each response, so the server needs only to provide =
limited, incremental information. Multiple Ajax requests can be handled at =
the same time, and users can interact with the page while data is retrieved=
. Web pages may also regularly [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polling_(com=
puter_science) | poll ] the server to check whether new information is avai=
lable. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-35 | [35] ]=
=20
WWW prefix [ [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=3DWorld_Wide_Web&=
action=3Dedit&section=3D5 | edit ] ]=20


Many hostnames used for the World Wide Web begin with www because of the lo=
ng-standing practice of naming Internet hosts according to the services the=
y provide. The [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hostname | hostname ] of a [=
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_server | web server ] is often www , in =
the same way that it may be ftp for an [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FTP_=
server | FTP server ] , and news or nntp for a [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w=
iki/USENET | USENET ] [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/News_server | news se=
rver ] . These host names appear as Domain Name System (DNS) or [ https://e=
n.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subdomain | subdomain ] names, as in www.testdomain.com .=
 The use of www is not required by any technical or policy standard and man=
y web sites do not use it; indeed, the first ever web server was called nxo=
c01.cern.ch . [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-36 |=
 [36] ] According to Paolo Palazzi, [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_W=
ide_Web#cite_note-37 | [37] ] who worked at CERN along with Tim Berners-Lee=
, the popular use of www as subdomain was accidental; the World Wide Web pr=
oject page was intended to be published at www.cern.ch while info.cern.ch w=
as intended to be the CERN home page, however the DNS records were never sw=
itched, and the practice of prepending www to an institution's website doma=
in name was subsequently copied. Many established websites still use the pr=
efix, or they employ other subdomain names such as www2 , secure or en for =
special purposes. Many such web servers are set up so that both the main do=
main name (e.g., testdomain.com) and the www subdomain (e.g., www.testdomain.com)=
 refer to the same site; others require one form or the other, or they may =
map to different web sites.=20

The use of a subdomain name is useful for [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L=
oad_balancing_(computing) | load balancing ] incoming web traffic by creati=
ng a [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNAME_record | CNAME record ] that poi=
nts to a cluster of web servers. Since, currently, only a subdomain can be =
used in a CNAME, the same result cannot be achieved by using the bare domai=
n root. [ [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed | citat=
ion needed ] ]=20

When a user submits an incomplete domain name to a web browser in its addre=
ss bar input field, some web browsers automatically try adding the prefix "=
www" to the beginning of it and possibly ".com", ".org" and ".net" at the e=
nd, depending on what might be missing. For example, entering 'microsoft' m=
ay be transformed to http://www.microsoft.com/ and 'openoffice' to http://w=
ww.openoffice.org . This feature started appearing in early versions of Moz=
illa [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Firefox | Firefox ] , when it still ha=
d the working title 'Firebird' in early 2003, from an earlier practice in b=
rowsers such as [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lynx_(web_browser) | Lynx ]=
 . [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-38 | [38] ] It =
is reported that Microsoft was granted a US patent for the same idea in 200=
8, but only for mobile devices. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_=
Web#cite_note-39 | [39] ]=20


In English, [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pronunciation_of_%22www%22 | ww=
w=C2=A0is usually read as ] double-u double-u double-u . [ https://en.wikip=
edia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-40 | [40] ] Some users pronounce it =
dub-dub-dub , particularly in New Zealand. Stephen Fry, in his "Podgrammes"=
 series of podcasts, pronounces it wuh wuh wuh . [ [ https://en.wikipedia.o=
rg/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed | citation needed ] ] The English writer =
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_Adams | Douglas Adams ] once quippe=
d in [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Independent | The Independent on S=
unday ] (1999): "The World Wide Web is the only thing I know of whose short=
ened form takes three times longer to say than what it's short for". [ http=
s://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-Sim-41 | [41] ] In Manda=
rin Chinese, World Wide Web is commonly translated via a [ https://en.wikip=
edia.org/wiki/Phono-semantic_matching | phono-semantic matching ] to w=C3=
=A0n w=C3=A9i w=C7=8Eng ( [ https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%87%E7%BB%=
B4%E7%BD%91 | =E4=B8=87=E7=BB=B4=E7=BD=91 ] ), which satisfies www and lite=
rally means "myriad dimensional net", [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World=
_Wide_Web#cite_note-42 | [42] ] a translation that reflects the design conc=
ept and proliferation of the World Wide Web. Tim Berners-Lee's web-space st=
ates that World Wide Web is officially spelled as three separate words, eac=
h capitalised, with no intervening hyphens. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki=
/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-43 | [43] ]=20


Use of the www prefix is declining as [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_2=
.0 | Web 2.0 ] [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_application | web applic=
ations ] seek to brand their domain names and make them easily pronounceabl=
e. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-cas-44 | [44] ]=
 As the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_web | mobile web ] grows in =
popularity, services like [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Mail | Gma=
il ] .com, [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outlook.com | Outlook.com ] , [ =
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MySpace | MySpace ] .com, [ https://en.wikipe=
dia.org/wiki/Facebook | Facebook ] .com and [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki=
/Twitter | Twitter ] .com are most often mentioned without adding "www." (o=
r, indeed, ".com") to the domain. Scheme specifiers [ [ https://en.wikipedi=
a.org/w/index.php?title=3DWorld_Wide_Web&action=3Dedit&section=3D6 | edit ]=
 ]=20


The scheme specifiers http:// and https:// at the start of a web [ https://=
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_Resource_Identifier | URI ] refer to [ https:=
//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypertext_Transfer_Protocol | Hypertext Transfer Pr=
otocol ] or [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_Secure | HTTP Secure ] , r=
espectively. They specify the communication protocol to use for the request=
 and response. The HTTP protocol is fundamental to the operation of the Wor=
ld Wide Web, and the added encryption layer in HTTPS is essential when brow=
sers send or retrieve confidential data, such as passwords or banking infor=
mation. Web browsers usually automatically prepend http:// to user-entered =
URIs, if omitted. Web security [ [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?tit=
le=3DWorld_Wide_Web&action=3Dedit&section=3D7 | edit ] ]=20


For [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Criminal | criminals ] , the web has be=
come the preferred way to spread [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malware | =
malware ] . [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cybercrime | Cybercrime ] on th=
e web can include [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identity_theft | identity=
 theft ] , [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fraud | fraud ] , [ https://en.w=
ikipedia.org/wiki/Espionage | espionage ] and [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wi=
ki/Intelligence_gathering | intelligence gathering ] . [ https://en.wikiped=
ia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-Ben-Itzhak-45 | [45] ] Web-based [ htt=
ps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vulnerability_(computing) | vulnerabilities ] no=
w outnumber traditional computer security concerns, [ https://en.wikipedia.=
org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-46 | [46] ] [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wi=
ki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-47 | [47] ] and as measured by [ https://en.wik=
ipedia.org/wiki/Google | Google ] , about one in ten web pages may contain =
malicious code. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-48=
 | [48] ] Most web-based [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attack_(computing)=
 | attacks ] take place on legitimate websites, and most, as measured by [ =
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sophos | Sophos ] , are hosted in the United =
States, China and Russia. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#ci=
te_note-Sophos-Q1-2008-49 | [49] ] The most common of all malware [ https:/=
/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Threat_(computer) | threats ] is [ https://en.wikipe=
dia.org/wiki/SQL_injection | SQL injection ] attacks against websites. [ ht=
tps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-50 | [50] ] Through HT=
ML and URIs, the Web was vulnerable to attacks like [ https://en.wikipedia.=
org/wiki/Cross-site_scripting | cross-site scripting ] (XSS) that came with=
 the introduction of JavaScript [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_=
Web#cite_note-FGHR-51 | [51] ] and were exacerbated to some degree by [ htt=
ps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_2.0 | Web 2.0 ] and Ajax [ https://en.wikipe=
dia.org/wiki/Web_design | web design ] that favors the use of scripts. [ ht=
tps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-52 | [52] ] Today by o=
ne estimate, 70% of all websites are open to XSS attacks on their users. [ =
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-53 | [53] ] [ https:=
//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phishing | phishing ] is another common threat to t=
he Web. "SA, the Security Division of EMC, today announced the findings of =
its January 2013 Fraud Report, estimating the global losses from phishing a=
t $1.5 Billion in 2012". [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cit=
e_note-First_Post-54 | [54] ] Two of the well-known phishing methods are Co=
vert Redirect and Open Redirect.=20

Proposed solutions vary to extremes. Large security vendors like [ https://=
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McAfee | McAfee ] already design governance and compl=
iance suites to meet post-9/11 regulations, [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki=
/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-55 | [55] ] and some, like [ https://en.wikipedia=
.org/wiki/Finjan | Finjan ] have recommended active real-time inspection of=
 code and all content regardless of its source. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/=
wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-Ben-Itzhak-45 | [45] ] Some have argued that =
for enterprise to see security as a business opportunity rather than a cost=
 center, [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-56 | [56]=
 ] "ubiquitous, always-on digital rights management" enforced in the infras=
tructure by a handful of organizations must replace the hundreds of compani=
es that today secure data and networks. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wor=
ld_Wide_Web#cite_note-57 | [57] ] [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_=
Zittrain | Jonathan Zittrain ] has said users sharing responsibility for co=
mputing safety is far preferable to locking down the Internet. [ https://en=
.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-58 | [58] ]=20
Privacy [ [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=3DWorld_Wide_Web&act=
ion=3Dedit&section=3D8 | edit ] ]=20
Main article: [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_privacy | Internet p=
rivacy ]=20


Every time a client requests a web page, the server can identify the reques=
t's IP address and usually logs it. Also, unless set not to do so, most web=
 browsers record requested web pages in a viewable history feature, and usu=
ally [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_cache | cache ] much of the conten=
t locally. Unless the server-browser communication uses HTTPS encryption, w=
eb requests and responses travel in plain text across the Internet and can =
be viewed, recorded, and cached by intermediate systems.=20

When a web page asks for, and the user supplies, [ https://en.wikipedia.org=
/wiki/Personally_identifiable_information | personally identifiable informa=
tion ] =E2=80=94such as their real name, address, e-mail address, etc.=E2=
=80=94web-based entities can associate current web traffic with that indivi=
dual. If the website uses [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_cookie | HTT=
P cookies ] , username and password authentication, or other tracking techn=
iques, it can relate other web visits, before and after, to the identifiabl=
e information provided. In this way it is possible for a web-based organisa=
tion to develop and build a profile of the individual people who use its si=
te or sites. It may be able to build a record for an individual that includ=
es information about their leisure activities, their shopping interests, th=
eir profession, and other aspects of their [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/=
Demographic_profile | demographic profile ] . These profiles are obviously =
of potential interest to marketeers, advertisers and others. Depending on t=
he website's [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terms_and_conditions | terms a=
nd conditions ] and the local laws that apply information from these profil=
es may be sold, shared, or passed to other organisations without the user b=
eing informed. For many ordinary people, this means little more than some u=
nexpected e-mails in their in-box, or some uncannily relevant advertising o=
n a future web page. For others, it can mean that time spent indulging an u=
nusual interest can result in a deluge of further targeted marketing that m=
ay be unwelcome. Law enforcement, counter terrorism and espionage agencies =
can also identify, target and track individuals based on their interests or=
 proclivities on the Web.=20

[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking | Social networking ] sit=
es try to get users to use their real names, interests, and locations. They=
 believe this makes the social networking experience more realistic, and th=
erefore more engaging for all their users. On the other hand, uploaded phot=
ographs or unguarded statements can be identified to an individual, who may=
 regret this exposure. Employers, schools, parents, and other relatives may=
 be influenced by aspects of social networking profiles that the posting in=
dividual did not intend for these audiences. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wik=
i/Cyberbullying | On-line bullies ] may make use of personal information to=
 harass or [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyberstalking | stalk ] users. M=
odern social networking websites allow fine grained control of the privacy =
settings for each individual posting, but these can be complex and not easy=
 to find or use, especially for beginners. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/=
World_Wide_Web#cite_note-59 | [59] ]=20


Photographs and videos posted onto websites have caused particular problems=
, as they can add a person's face to an on-line profile. With modern and po=
tential [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facial_recognition_system | facial =
recognition technology ] , it may then be possible to relate that face with=
 other, previously anonymous, images, events and scenarios that have been i=
maged elsewhere. Because of image caching, mirroring and copying, it is dif=
ficult to remove an image from the World Wide Web. Standards [ [ https://en=
.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=3DWorld_Wide_Web&action=3Dedit&section=3D9=
 | edit ] ]=20
Main article: [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_standards | Web standards=
 ]=20


Many formal standards and other technical specifications and software defin=
e the operation of different aspects of the World Wide Web, the Internet, a=
nd computer information exchange. Many of the documents are the work of the=
 World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), headed by Berners-Lee, but some are produ=
ced by the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Engineering_Task_Force =
| Internet Engineering Task Force ] (IETF) and other organizations.=20

Usually, when web standards are discussed, the following publications are s=
een as foundational:=20

    * Recommendations for [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markup_languages =
| markup languages ] , especially [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML | HT=
ML ] and [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XHTML | XHTML ] , from the W3C. Th=
ese define the structure and interpretation of hypertext documents.=20
    * Recommendations for [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Style_sheet_(web_=
development) | stylesheets ] , especially [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C=
ascading_Style_Sheets | CSS ] , from the W3C.=20
    * Standards for ECMAScript (usually in the form of JavaScript), from [ =
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecma_International | Ecma International ] .=
=20
    * Recommendations for the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Document_Obje=
ct_Model | Document Object Model ] , from W3C.=20



Additional publications provide definitions of other essential technologies=
 for the World Wide Web, including, but not limited to, the following:=20

    * Uniform Resource Identifier (URI), which is a universal system for re=
ferencing resources on the Internet, such as hypertext documents and images=
. URIs, often called URLs, are defined by the IETF's [ https://tools.ietf.o=
rg/html/rfc3986 | RFC 3986 ] / STD 66: Uniform Resource Identifier (URI): G=
eneric Syntax , as well as its predecessors and numerous [ https://en.wikip=
edia.org/wiki/URI_scheme | URI scheme ] -defining [ https://en.wikipedia.or=
g/wiki/Request_For_Comments | RFCs ] ;=20
    * HyperText Transfer Protocol (HTTP) , especially as defined by [ https=
://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2616 | RFC 2616 ] : HTTP/1.1 and [ https://tools.=
ietf.org/html/rfc2617 | RFC 2617 ] : HTTP Authentication , which specify ho=
w the browser and server authenticate each other.=20

Accessibility [ [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=3DWorld_Wide_W=
eb&action=3Dedit&section=3D10 | edit ] ]=20
Main article: [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_accessibility | Web acces=
sibility ]=20


There are methods for accessing the Web in alternative mediums and formats =
to facilitate use by individuals with disabilities. These disabilities may =
be visual, auditory, physical, speech related, cognitive, neurological, or =
some combination. Accessibility features also help people with temporary di=
sabilities, like a broken arm, or aging users as their abilities change. [ =
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-WAI-60 | [60] ] The =
Web receives information as well as providing information and interacting w=
ith society. The World Wide Web Consortium claims it essential that the Web=
 be accessible, so it can provide equal access and [ https://en.wikipedia.o=
rg/wiki/Equal_opportunity | equal opportunity ] to people with disabilities=
. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-61 | [61] ] Tim =
Berners-Lee once noted, "The power of the Web is in its universality. Acces=
s by everyone regardless of disability is an essential aspect." [ https://e=
n.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-WAI-60 | [60] ] Many countrie=
s regulate [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_accessibility | web accessib=
ility ] as a requirement for websites. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worl=
d_Wide_Web#cite_note-62 | [62] ] International cooperation in the W3C [ htt=
ps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_Accessibility_Initiative | Web Accessibility=
 Initiative ] led to simple guidelines that web content authors as well as =
software developers can use to make the Web accessible to persons who may o=
r may not be using [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assistive_technology | a=
ssistive technology ] . [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite=
_note-WAI-60 | [60] ] [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_n=
ote-63 | [63] ]=20
Internationalization [ [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=3DWorld=
_Wide_Web&action=3Dedit&section=3D11 | edit ] ]=20


The W3C [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationalization_and_localizati=
on | Internationalization ] Activity assures that web technology works in a=
ll languages, scripts, and cultures. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_=
Wide_Web#cite_note-64 | [64] ] Beginning in 2004 or 2005, [ https://en.wiki=
pedia.org/wiki/Unicode | Unicode ] gained ground and eventually in December=
 2007 surpassed both [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASCII | ASCII ] and We=
stern European as the Web's most frequently used [ https://en.wikipedia.org=
/wiki/Character_encoding | character encoding ] . [ https://en.wikipedia.or=
g/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-65 | [65] ] Originally [ https://tools.ietf=
.org/html/rfc3986 | RFC 3986 ] allowed resources to be identified by [ http=
s://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/URI | URI ] in a subset of US-ASCII. [ https://to=
ols.ietf.org/html/rfc3987 | RFC 3987 ] allows more characters=E2=80=94any c=
haracter in the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_Character_Set | U=
niversal Character Set ] =E2=80=94and now a resource can be identified by [=
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationalized_Resource_Identifier | IRI =
] in any language. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note=
-66 | [66] ]=20
Statistics [ [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=3DWorld_Wide_Web&=
action=3Dedit&section=3D12 | edit ] ]=20


Between 2005 and 2010, the number of web users doubled, and was expected to=
 surpass two billion in 2010. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_We=
b#cite_note-67 | [67] ] Early studies in 1998 and 1999 estimating the size =
of the Web using capture/recapture methods showed that much of the web was =
not indexed by search engines and the Web was much larger than expected. [ =
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-68 | [68] ] [ https:=
//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-69 | [69] ] According to a=
 2001 study, there was a massive number, over 550 billion, of documents on =
the Web, mostly in the invisible Web, or [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De=
ep_Web_(search_indexing) | Deep Web ] . [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wor=
ld_Wide_Web#cite_note-70 | [70] ] A 2002 survey of 2,024 million web pages =
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-71 | [71] ] determ=
ined that by far the most web content was in the English language: 56.4%; n=
ext were pages in German (7.7%), French (5.6%), and Japanese (4.9%). A more=
 recent study, which used web searches in 75 different languages to sample =
the Web, determined that there were over 11.5 billion web pages in the [ ht=
tps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surface_Web | publicly indexable web ] as of th=
e end of January 2005. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_=
note-72 | [72] ] As of March 2009, the indexable web contains at least 25.2=
1 billion pages. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-7=
3 | [73] ] On 25 July 2008, Google software engineers Jesse Alpert and Niss=
an Hajaj announced that [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Search | Goo=
gle Search ] had discovered one trillion unique URLs. [ https://en.wikipedi=
a.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-74 | [74] ] As of May 2009, over 109.5 =
million domains operated. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#ci=
te_note-NI-75 | [75] ] [ [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiab=
ility | not in citation given ] ] Of these, 74% were commercial or other do=
mains operating in the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generic_top-level_do=
main | generic top-level domain ] com . [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wor=
ld_Wide_Web#cite_note-NI-75 | [75] ]=20


Statistics measuring a website's popularity are usually based either on the=
 number of [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Page_view | page views ] or on a=
ssociated server ' [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hit_(internet) | hits ] =
' (file requests) that it receives. Speed issues [ [ https://en.wikipedia.o=
rg/w/index.php?title=3DWorld_Wide_Web&action=3Dedit&section=3D13 | edit ] ]=
=20


Frustration over [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_congestion | conge=
stion ] issues in the Internet infrastructure and the high [ https://en.wik=
ipedia.org/wiki/Latency_(engineering) | latency ] that results in slow brow=
sing has led to a pejorative name for the World Wide Web: the World Wide Wa=
it . [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-76 | [76] ] S=
peeding up the Internet is an ongoing discussion over the use of [ https://=
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peering | peering ] and [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wi=
ki/Quality_of_service | QoS ] technologies. Other solutions to reduce the c=
ongestion can be found at [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/W3C | W3C ] . [ h=
ttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-77 | [77] ] [ https:/=
/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guideline | Guidelines ] for web response times are:=
 [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-78 | [78] ]=20


    * 0.1 second (one tenth of a second). Ideal response time. The user doe=
s not sense any interruption.=20
    * 1 second. Highest acceptable response time. Download times above 1 se=
cond interrupt the user experience.=20
    * 10 seconds. Unacceptable response time. The user experience is interr=
upted and the user is likely to leave the site or system.=20

Web caching [ [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=3DWorld_Wide_Web=
&action=3Dedit&section=3D14 | edit ] ]=20


A [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_cache | web cache ] is a server compu=
ter located either on the public Internet, or within an enterprise that sto=
res recently accessed web pages to improve response time for users when the=
 same content is requested within a certain time after the original request=
.=20

Most web browsers also implement a [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Browser_=
cache | browser cache ] for recently obtained data, usually on the local di=
sk drive. HTTP requests by a browser may ask only for data that has changed=
 since the last access. Web pages and resources may contain expiration info=
rmation to control caching to secure sensitive data, such as in [ https://e=
n.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_banking | online banking ] , or to facilitate f=
requently updated sites, such as news media. Even sites with highly dynamic=
 content may permit basic resources to be refreshed only occasionally. Web =
site designers find it worthwhile to collate resources such as CSS data and=
 JavaScript into a few site-wide files so that they can be cached efficient=
ly.=20

Enterprise [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Firewall_(networking) | firewall=
s ] often cache Web resources requested by one user for the benefit of many=
. Some [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_engines | search engines ] st=
ore cached content of frequently accessed websites. See also [ [ https://en=
.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=3DWorld_Wide_Web&action=3Dedit&section=3D1=
5 | edit ] ]=20
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Crystal_Clear_app_browser.png ]=20

blishing ]=20

rs ]=20

 ]=20

 ]=20

=20

nt tools ]=20

    * [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_literacy | Web literacy ]=20

    * [ https://fiu-vro.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWW | V=C3=B5ro ]=20

World Wide Web=20
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia=20

[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#mw-head ] [ https://en.wikip=
edia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#p-search ]=20
"WWW" and "The web" redirect here. For other uses of WWW, see [ https://en.=
wikipedia.org/wiki/WWW_(disambiguation) | WWW (disambiguation) ] . For othe=
r uses of web, see [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_(disambiguation) | W=
eb (disambiguation) ] .=20
For the first web software, see [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WorldWideWe=
b | WorldWideWeb ] .=20


The World Wide Web ( WWW ) is an [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_sourc=
e | open source ] [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_space | infor=
mation space ] where documents and other [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/We=
b_resource | web resources ] are identified by [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w=
iki/URL | URLs ] , interlinked by [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypertext=
 | hypertext ] links, and can be accessed via the [ https://en.wikipedia.or=
g/wiki/Internet | Internet ] . [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_W=
eb#cite_note-1 | [1] ] The World Wide Web was invented by English scientist=
 [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee | Tim Berners-Lee ] in 198=
9. He wrote the first web browser in 1990 while employed at [ https://en.wi=
kipedia.org/wiki/CERN | CERN ] in Switzerland. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/w=
iki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-2 | [2] ] [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worl=
d_Wide_Web#cite_note-AHT-3 | [3] ]=20


It has become known simply as the Web . The World Wide Web was central to t=
he development of the [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_Age | Inf=
ormation Age ] and is the primary tool billions of people use to interact o=
n the Internet. [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-4 =
| [4] ] [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-5 | [5] ] =
[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web#cite_note-6 | [6] ]=20


[ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_page | Web pages ] are primarily [ http=
s://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plain_text | text ] documents formatted and annot=
ated with [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypertext_Markup_Language | Hyper=
text Markup Language ] (HTML). In addition to formatted text, web pages may=
 contain [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image | images ] , [ https://en.wi=
kipedia.org/wiki/Video | video ] , and software components that are rendere=
d in the user's [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_browser | web browser ]=
 as coherent pages of [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimedia | multimed=
ia ] content. Embedded [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperlink | hyperlin=
ks ] permit users to [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_navigation | navig=
ate ] between web pages. Multiple web pages with a common theme, a common [=
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_name | domain name ] , or both, may b=
e called a [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Website | website ] . Website co=
ntent can largely be provided by the publisher, or interactive where users =
contribute content or the content depends upon the user or their actions. W=
ebsites may be mostly informative, primarily for entertainment, or largely =
for commercial purposes.=20


Contents=20
[ [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web# | hide ] ]=20

ng ]=20

_web_pages | 2.2Dynamic updates of web pages ]=20

W prefix ]=20

| 2.4Scheme specifiers ]=20

curity ]=20

 ]=20

sibility ]=20

 7Internationalization ]=20

cs ]=20

issues ]=20

ching ]=20

]=20

rther reading ]=20

ernal links ]=20
